title: One-minute questions
text:
After each class session, you are expected to give a brief summary of what happened in that session as well as pointing to things that either 1) were particularly meaningful to you or 2) that you found confusing.
These are called one-minute questions to indicate roughly how much time you should spend on your answer. Of course, you are welcome to spend more time. But even if you spend just one minute, your answer should be honest, articulate, and aimed at improving the class for yourself and your student colleagues.
DO NOT write your answer while still in class.


One-minute questions






WarningRemember to hand in your work â€¦






Submitting answersClearing document memory


At any point, you can submit your answers by collecting them and uploading them to the class site.

title: About
text:
At the University of Austin, our students pursue a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Studies. As part of their required course of study, students must complete a core curriculum called the Intellectual Foundations, which consists of 15 intensive courses that introduce students to the various languages of understanding and teach them to see things whole. As part of this sequence, students are challenged to confront timeless questions beginning in antiquity and culminating in the present day.
There are two quantitative reasoning courses in the Intellectual Foundation curriculum. These are:

Quantitative Reasoning I (â€œQR â€” Analysisâ€), which teaches students the mathematical modeling tools useful for modelling real-world phenomena.
Quantitative Reasoning II (â€œQR â€” Dataâ€), which teaches students to extract useful information from data using modern data science techniques.

Both QR â€” Analysis and QR â€” Data are unlike the introductory courses found at almost all other colleges and universities. We have selected topics based on their utility in modern professional work. In contrast, basic topics in the traditional curriculum reflect the historical development of mathematics rather than the needs of modern work. Modern topics widely used in the economy and scientific/technical worlds are relegated to so-called â€œadvancedâ€ courses far downstream where they are inaccessible to almost all students.
Our two QR courses dramatically streamline the pre-requisites for successful work with modern quantitative topics. Surprisingly often the â€œadvancedâ€ topics are readily accessible to students, so long as one is willing to move beyond traditional pedagogy and avoid unwarranted devotion to topics that were important historically but are no longer necessarily for understanding.

NoteChap 1: Models






Exercise W1. 1 Many people experience the symptoms of a housing shortage: splitting up apartments to accomodate roommate groups; financial stress due (in part) to high rents; deferring life decisions such as having children; living in deteriorating, aging buildings, and so on.
Weâ€™re used to thinking about people in terms of lifespan, but it is also useful to think about buildings that way. City and local governments keep detailed information about the housing stock, largely for tax purposes. Services like <zillow.com> have data readily available to the public.
Question: What about the houses listed on Zillow might presented a view biased to houses in better condition?
A life-cycle assessment of a sample of US houses and apartments by Aktas and Bilic (2012) produced the following graphic about how long houses and apartments remain habitable.






Figure W1.Â 1: â€œLifetime distribution of residential buildings calculated from multiple American Housing Survey microdata,â€ from Aktas and Bilic 2012.



Question: Is the graph consistent with the claim that 7% of US housing stock was built before 1920?
Question: Speculate on what might account for the rightward shift of the curve over the ten year period considered. Consider these two hypotheses:

house building techniques have been improving. (When would they have had to improve to produce the curve shift?)
the current housing shortage has resulted in buildings being used after the time that they would have been replaced were there no housing shortage?

ANOTHER DATUM: â€œIn the U.S., the typical depreciation rate for a residential apartment building is 3.636% per year. The IRS requires that the cost of the building (minus the value of the land) be depreciated over a period of 27.5 years using the straight-line method.â€ from AI
Iâ€™M HEADING TOWARD a later exercise referring to Chapter 8 or 9 in *short introduction to demography which will ask students to outline their own design for a model that would enable us to construct an index of how successfully new housing suitable for different income levels is becoming available to accomodate growth and the retirement of old buildings.



Exercise W1. 2 Consider this simple, made-up mortality table that might be representative of a bird species, e.g.Â robins.

Calculate the life expectancy for these birds. Give a number, but also explain you reasoning in words. (Hint: Itâ€™s not a long calculation.)

Assigned to DTK



Exercise W1. 3 Short classroom discussion about the SIR model graphic including:

a quick demonstration (narrated by the students) of the patterns seen for different settings of the parameters.
speculate on how to operationalize â€œsocial distance.â€
reason why the isolation parameter only goes up to 50%: the behavior doesnâ€™t change much for higher isolations. Explain that % for isolation means the fraction of the infectives who isolate or, equivalently, how much of the time infectives isolate.

title: Student responsibilities
text: Student responsibilities

title: UATX Quantitative Reasoning - Analysis
text:
This is the course homepage for UATX INF 1130 (Quantitative Reasoning I). All course materials can be found through this website, and information will be updated throughout the term. This site is designed for students, but visitors are welcome. General information for visitors is available via the About page.
A typical class week consists of one or two of the topics from the textbook and includes textbook readings, homework questions, and a short weekly quiz.

title: Weekly Materials
text:
CautionDevelopment Note:





This is where we will list the readings, assignments, quiz days, and other components for each class session. The formatting is subject to change.



This page provides an archive of the topics, class materials, and homework assignments used in the course. This page is kept up-to-date throughout the term.







CautionRemember to hand in your work!





Much of your work for the class will take the form of completing interactive web documents. Near the top of each such document, there is a highlighted box very similar to this on. To hand in your work, open that box and press â€œCollect your answersâ€. This will copy your essay and multiple-choice answers to your clipboard, in preparation for uploading them to the courseâ€™s collection site.
After pressing **â€œCollect your answersâ€* to the the follow the link to upload site. This leads to a Google form providing space for your email address and for pasting your answers from the clipboard. The same link will be used for the entire course.
Finally, press the â€œSubmitâ€ button on the Google form. Done!






TipMore details about the submission process â€¦





Please do not edit the clipboard string. Itâ€™s intended for computer-to-computer communication and will look something like this.
{"docid":"One-minute.rmarkdown","MC":[],"Essays":[{"itemid":"1-min-week1-a","contents":"The class was great!"},{"itemid":"1-min-week1-b","contents":"Even better today!"}}
There may be many empty fields in the string; that is as it should be.
So long as you are using the same browser on the same computer, your answers will continue to appear in the web document each time you open it. (DONâ€™T CONFUSE THIS with submitting your work. For us to receive it, it has to be submitted via the Google form.) You can go back to the web document whenever you like. So feel free to do your work in stages, perhaps spread over a couple of days.
When in doubt whether your work has been submitted, submit it again! The computerized collection system will take care of any duplications.












NoteEvery week






One-minute essays. These should be submitted by end of day (11:59 PM) after every class meeting.
A Quiz will be given once per week at the first class meeting of that week. Usually this is Monday (for section 001) or Tuesday (for sections 003 & 004).Quizzes will be short (under 10 minutes) and delivered in-class.







Reading: Chapters 1 and 2 of the QR-A textbook. Answer the Reading Questions for Chap-1 & Chap-2. In later weeks you will be asked to submit these before your class session.







TipAssignment 1






Link to assignment document
Quiz: Mon Jan 12 or Tues Jan 13. Note that this is before the submission deadline.
Submission deadline: Start of your class Wed Jan 14 or Thurs Jan 15.









Quiz covering Week 1 material in your Mon/Tues class.
Mon/Tues Reading: Chapter 3 of QR-A. Answer and submit the Reading Questions before your class meeting.
Wed/Thurs Reading: Chapter 4 of QR-A. Answer and submit the Reading Questions before your class meeting.





Quiz Mon/Tues covering Weeks 1 and 2 material.
Mon/Tues Reading: Chapter 5 of QR-A. Answer and submit the Reading Questions before your class meeting.







TipAssignment 2






Link to assignment document
Submission deadline: Start of your class Wed Jan 21 or Thurs Jan 22.

NoteChapter One






1.2.3.



Exercise 1 Many people experience the symptoms of a housing shortage: splitting up apartments to accomodate roommate groups; financial stress due (in part) to high rents; deferring life decisions such as having children; living in deteriorating, aging buildings, and so on.
Weâ€™re used to thinking about people in terms of lifespan, but it is also useful to think about buildings that way. City and local governments keep detailed information about the housing stock, largely for tax purposes. Services like <zillow.com> have data readily available to the public.
Question: What about the houses listed on Zillow might presented a view biased to houses in better condition?


A life-cycle assessment of a sample of US houses and apartments by Aktas and Bilic (2012) produced the following graphic about how long houses and apartments remain habitable.






FigureÂ 1: â€œLifetime distribution of residential buildings calculated from multiple American Housing Survey microdata,â€ from Aktas and Bilic 2012.



Question: Is the graph consistent with the claim that 7% of US housing stock was built before 1920?


Question: Speculate on what might account for the rightward shift of the curve over the ten year period considered. Consider these two hypotheses:

house building techniques have been improving. (When would they have had to improve to produce the curve shift?)
the current housing shortage has resulted in buildings being used after the time that they would have been replaced were there no housing shortage?









Exercise 2 Consider this simple, made-up mortality table that might be representative of a bird species, e.g.Â robins.



Age
Mortality
Starting Population




0

1000


1
0.50
500


2
0.50
250


3
1.00
125


4

0



Calculate the life expectancy for these birds. Give a number, but also explain you reasoning in words. (Hint: Itâ€™s not a long calculation.)






NOTE: The version of the SIR model built-in to Chapter 1 of the textbook does not work reliably. Use this link to access the model via a different web service. Follow the Models/SIR menu at the top of the new page.

Exercise 3 Using the SIR model in the text: (NOTE: Some students have experienced problems getting the SIR model to load. If you are among these, work with a colleague whose SIR model is functional. Sorry for the inconvenience.)

Describe the behavior of the number of infected persons with time in cases of the following policy options:

Social Distancing = 9â€™; Isolation = 10%
Social Distancing = 3â€™; Isolation = 40%





How many people ultimately are infected under each of these policies?




Which of these is preferable to the other, and why?

















NoteDrill for chapter two





Open drill questions in this document
Remember to submit your drill answers through that document. But for the exercises in the present document, use the â€œcollect answersâ€ at the top of this page.









NoteChapter Two






4.5.6.7.8.9.10.



Exercise 4 Name five units for energy. Remember that â€œpowerâ€ has a different dimension than energy.







Exercise 5 Light bulbs generally have a quantity printed on them: the wattage. Similarly, light-bulb sockets often have a â€œmax wattsâ€ label advising the user of the largest wattage bulb that can work safely in the socket.

Part a

What is the dimension of a watt?



 bulb-wattage

   Energy Â Â Â Â Â   Power Â Â Â Â Â   Electrical voltage Â Â Â Â Â   Electrical current Â Â Â Â Â    











TipAnswer





Since people donâ€™t directly perceive electrical current or voltage, it is hard to form an intuition about them. Instead, training is required to interpret properly the meanings of electrical dimensions.
An exact mathematical analogy to electrical dimensions can be made to water and flow. You turn on the shower and step in for four minutes. As you shower, at each instant you can feel the â€œintensityâ€ (flow) of the spray from the shower-head. You even have a faucet to set the flow. This flow is analogous to the power used by a light bulb.
Over the full course of your 4-minute shower, six gallons of water goes down the train. Gallons, of course, have the dimension of volume. You used those six gallons over four minutes. Consequently, the flow of water is \(\frac{6\, \text{gallons}}{4\, \text{minutes}} = 1.5\, \text{gallons per minute}\). The volume of water used in your shower session is analogous to the energy used by a light bulb: it is power multiplied by duration. ..id..





Part b

The brightness of the light emitted by a light bulb is proportional to power. Suppose you turn on a 20-watt light when you walk into a room. This consumes energy. The energy used by the bulb is the power multiplied by the duration that the light was on.



If you stay in the room for 1 hour, turning off the light when you leave, how much energy has the light consumed?


 light-bulb-b1

   20 watts Â Â Â Â Â   20 watt-hours Â Â Â Â Â   Not enough information is given Â Â Â Â Â   1 hour Â Â Â Â Â    





In terms of the fundamental dimensionsâ€”L, M, Tâ€”energy has dimension L2 M T-2. What is the dimension of power?


 light-bulb-b2

   L2 M T-1 Â Â Â Â Â   L2 M T-2 Â Â Â Â Â   L2 M T-3 Â Â Â Â Â    





You might reasonably ask, â€œWhat does mass have to do with energy?â€ Perhaps you remember Einsteinâ€™s famous equation for energy: \[E = m\, c^2\] where \(m\) is mass and \(c\) is the speed of light. What is the dimension of \(c^2\)?


 light-bulb-b3

   L T Â Â Â Â Â   L Â Â Â Â Â   L T-1 Â Â Â Â Â   L T-2 Â Â Â Â Â   L2 T-2 Â Â Â Â Â    




Consequently, \(m\, c^2\) has the dimension of energy.

Part c

Consider this statement:



Power consumption is a property of the light bulb, but energy consumption involves both the light bulb itself and the pattern of usage.

Â Â   light-bulb-c1

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    




Part d

A typical household uses about 10 kilowatt-hours of energy per day. â€œ10 kilowatt-hoursâ€ is an amount of energy, but â€œenergy per dayâ€ is a flow of energy, that is, a power.



Translate â€œ10 kilowatt-hours of energy per dayâ€ into the equivalent watts. For simplicity in the calculation, assume that the energy is used evenly over the 24-hour day.


 light-bulb-d1

   417 watts Â Â Â Â Â   10,000 watts Â Â Â Â Â   240,000 watts Â Â Â Â Â   Not enough information Â Â Â Â Â    





Look up the power consumption of a hand-held blow-dryer. When the blow-dryer is in use, energy consumption of the household increases. Which of these is a plausible fraction of average household power consumed by the hair-dryer?


 light-bulb-d2

   10% of average power Â Â Â Â Â   50% of average power Â Â Â Â Â   100% of average power Â Â Â Â Â   200% of average power Â Â Â Â Â    









Exercise 6 Perhaps unsurprisingly, the power of an automobile engine has the dimension of power.
Imagine a car with a 100 horsepower engine. What is the equivalent value in units of watts.

 light-bulb-e3


 735.5 watts


 7355 watts


 73,550 watts











Exercise 7 Chapter 2 quoted a list from Arithmetic for the practical man by J.E. Thompson (1931). He wrote:

Common measurements are of several kinds â€¦. The chief of the common measurements are those of

Length
Surface, or area
Volume, or capacity
Weight, or force of gravity
Time
Angles, latitude and longitude
Temperature, or intensity of heat
Money, or value


Annotate each item of Thompsonâ€™s list with the dimension. Indicate whether it is a basic dimension or a derived dimension.

Put basic dimensions here:


Put derived dimensions here:








TipAnswer






Length, L
Surface, or area L \(\times\) L, which we will generally write L2
Volume, or capacity L \(\times\) L \(\times\) L, which we will generally write L3
Weight, or force of gravity M \(\times\) L / T2, or, written another way, M L T-2
Time, T
Angles, latitude and longitude [1]
Temperature, or intensity of heat ğ›³
Money, or value W

Note that four of them (i, v, vii, and viii) are tautologies.
..id..









Exercise 8 The Economist is considered one of the worldâ€™s leading news magazines. Here is part of an article entitled â€œFear the deficit-populism doom loopâ€ from Aug 24, 2025.

You are a finance minister after a decade of meagre economic growth, shocks from a financial crisis, a pandemic and sky-high energy prices. Public debt is worth more than your countryâ€™s gross domestic product, interest rates are at their highest in years and merely servicing outstanding debt is taking up an ever-greater share of tax revenue. Inflation is stubborn. Americaâ€™s profligacy is satisfying much of the worldâ€™s appetite for government bonds, meaning your debt must pay more to attract investors. You lie awake worrying about how to make the numbers add up.


What are the dimensions of public debt? S in units of whatever is the relevant currency.




What are the dimensions of gross domestic product? S T-1




Itâ€™s quantitatively incorrect to compare public debt with gross domestic product.

What dimension must the quantity be that multiplies gross domestic product in order to convert it to a quantity that is directly comparable with public debt?
Letâ€™s give the name B to the quantity in (i). You know the dimension of B, but to perform the multiplication you need to choose a value for B. Is there a value for B that is obviously correct? If you say â€œno,â€ explain why not. If you say â€œyes,â€ explain the reasoning behind its being obvious.




The Economist article continues:

This is the bind facing governments in much of the rich world. The average fiscal deficit in the OECD, a club of mostly rich countries, hit 4.6% of GDP last year, up from an average of 2.9% in the four years before the covid-19 pandemic; interest payments on outstanding debt came to 3.3% of GDP, only just below the amount Nato members hope to spend on defence by 2035. The political-science literature offers some comfortâ€”austerity is not usually a barrier to re-electionâ€”but also a warning. Research shows a link between spending cuts and populist success. Indeed, in Britain, France and Germany such parties are already ascendant. Call it the deficit-populism doom loop: ministers face both big deficits and voter revolts, and there is little way of satisfying both the bond markets and the barbarians at the gate.


If fiscal deficit can be stated as a percentage of GDP, what does that say about the dimension of fiscal deficit?




Explain whatâ€™s different between fiscal deficit and debt.




Fiscal deficit can be reckoned as the sum of 1) interest payments on the debt (3.3%) and 2) the amount of other spending (on education, pensions, military, etc.) in excess of government income (taxes, etc.) By what percentage would spending need to decrease or taxes need to increase in order to eliminate the fiscal deficit?








Exercise 9 There are several ways to measure transportation services. Letâ€™s focus here on the transportation of people. The distance of transport is, obviously, an important aspect of transportation services. So it the number of people transported.
In a proper measure of transportation services, it seems reasonable that the longer the distance, the more transportation being provided, so long as the number of passengers is the same. Similarly, the more passengers carried, so long as the distance is the same, the more transportation is provided.

Which of the following is a sensible way to measure the amount of transportation?


 prw-base-wlci


 People plus miles


 People per mile


 Miles per person


 Miles \(\times \sqrt{\strut\text{person}}\)


 Persons \(\times\) miles







100 passengers are on a flight covering 500 miles. How much transportation service is provided to the group of passengers?


 prw-2-cksd


 500 passenger miles


 5000 passenger miles


 50,000 passenger miles


 500,000 passenger miles.






Many people are concerned with the amount of fuel used in air travel. For modern jets (with a full load of passengers), the amount of fuel used is approximately 0.02 to 0.03 gallons per passenger mile.

What is the dimension of â€œgallons per passenger mile?â€


 prw-3-kdlw


 L^4 C-1


 L^3 C-1


 L^2 C-1


 L C-1







People in the US are used to measuring fuel economy in â€œmiles per gallon.â€ This contrasts with the style in much of the rest of the world the unit is â€œliters per 100 km.â€ Assume that a group of friends is travelling 600 miles to a concert. They could fly or drive. If there are three friends, how many gallons of fuel will the one-way air travel consume (for these three passengers)? (Pick the closest answer.)


 prw-4-cksd


 15 gallons


 30 gallons


 150 gallons


 300 gallons







Now imagine the three friends are carpooling to the concert in a car that gets 30 miles per gallon. How many gallons of fuel will the one-way drive consume for all three passengers. (Pick the closest answer.)


 prw-5-wels


 20 gallons


 60 gallons


 200 gallons


 300 gallons







Some people reason that it does not consume any fuel for the three friends to fly, since even if they didnâ€™t fly the plane would consume the same amount of fuel. Are you sympathetic to this argument? Explain why or why not.








Exercise 10 Figure 2.1 displays child mortality versus gross domestic product (GDP) on a country-by-country basis. Child mortality is operationalized as the number of children who die between birth and their fifth birthday. It is a â€œrateâ€ because the number given is a ratio of the number of deaths in this group to the total number of children in this group, but is given in units of â€œdeaths per 1000 children.â€ That is, the ratio is dimensionless with dimension C C-1 = [1], (Strictly speaking, the rate should be called â€œUnder-five mortality.â€)
GDP is often presented as the value of goods and services produced by a country in one year. The quantity shown here is also a rate, described in the label of the graph as â€œGDP per capita.â€ The dimension of the GDP is W T-1 C-1. The operationalization of GDP is defined in a way that makes it relatively easy to measure from government and commercial records. All goods and services for which money is exchanged are included. No goods and services for which money is not exchanged are included. Thus, GDP ignores the value provided by, for instance, home child care and home meal preparation. A country which switched from home-cooked meals to fast food would see a sharp increase in GDP but, perhaps, a decrease in nutrition. Paid work need not be productive to be included in GDP. No adjustment is made for losses due to accidents, disasters, or depreciation of buildings and other capital.
Another factor not included in GDP is the price level in each country. Price levels vary from country to country and also from year to year. In Figure 2.1, not only is a comparison made between countries, but also between years. GDP numbers used for international or inter-year comparison are often, as here, adjusted for the â€œprice levelâ€ in each country in each year. The price level is determined by what it costs to buy a â€œmarket basketâ€ of goods. And that price level varies over the years, a process we call â€œinflation.â€
The GDP per capita presented in Figure 2.1 is adjusted for price level. The adjustment is often referred to as PPP, short for purchasing power parity. The units are 2011 â€œInternational Dollars,â€ a hypothetical currency for comparison between countries.











FigureÂ 2: Child mortality (deaths per 1000) versus GDP for 1960 and 2020. Source: Bolt and van Zanden â€“ Maddison Project Database 2023 â€“ with minor processing by [Our World in Data].




Find two countries (in the same year) that have almost the same GDP but very different mortality rates.




Find two countries (in the same year) that have almost the same mortality, but very different GDPs.




Describe the overall relationship between GDP and child mortality, as best you can discern from these data.

NoteDrill for Chapter 3





Open drill questions in this document
Remember to submit your drill answers through that document. But for the exercises in the present document, use the â€œcollect answersâ€ at the top of this page.









NoteChapter Three






1.2.



Exercise 1 The following is from the Atlantic magazine article, â€œScience Is Winning the Tour de Franceâ€ (by Matt Seaton, July 25, 2025)

The gold standard of cycling performanceâ€”which boils down to a riderâ€™s ability to push against the wind and go uphill fastâ€”is a high power-to-weight ratio, given in watts per kilogram. The benchmark figure is how many watts per kilo a cyclist can sustain for a one-hour effort. Every rider now has a power meter fitted to their bike, so they know their numbers in a constant, real-time way (together with heart rate, speed, and other measurements).

The article describes the then-current leader in the Tour de France as having a power-to-weight ratio of seven watts per kilogram.

If this rider weighs 70 kg, how many watts can he generate?


 sbk-1-vsw

   49 watts Â Â Â Â Â   70 watts Â Â Â Â Â   490 watts Â Â Â Â Â   700 watts Â Â Â Â Â    





Look up the conversion factor from watts to horsepower. How many horsepower is the rider generating?


 sbk-2-ie2d

   0.066 hp Â Â Â Â Â   0.660 hp Â Â Â Â Â   6.60 hp Â Â Â Â Â   66.0 hp Â Â Â Â Â    





A horse weighing 500 kg can generate one horsepower while walking. How does the horseâ€™s power efficiency per weight compare to the champion bike rider.


 sbk-3-r7f


 Horse 7 W/kg versus human 1.4 W/kg


 Human 7 W/kg versus horse 1.4 W/g


 Human 7 W/kg versus horse 2.8 W/kg


 Horse 70 W/kg versus human 280 W/kg







There is no conversion factor from watts to calories. Why not?


 sbk-4-ri3


 One is metric units, the other is â€œtraditionalâ€ units.


 You canâ€™t compare light-bulbs to food!


 They have different dimensions.


 Thatâ€™s wrong. There is a conversion factor.







Look up the conversion factor from watt-seconds to kilo-calories (kcal (or â€œCalâ€), the relevant unit when looking at diet). How many kcal does the rider produce when biking for one hour at 7 w/kg?


 sbk-5-nsl2

   211 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   422 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   633 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   844 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   1688 kcal Â Â Â Â Â    




1 watt-second is 0.000239006 kcal. In an hour, the rider generates 3600 s times 70 kg times 7 w/kg = 422 kcal

Itâ€™s estimated that a personâ€™s efficiency when converting dietary calories to work/movement calories is about 25%. In an hour of biking at 7 w/kg, how many dietary calories does a 70-kg rider consume?


 sbk-6-fjfk

   211 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   422 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   633 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   844 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   1688 kcal Â Â Â Â Â    





An â€œaverageâ€ adult walking at 2.5 mi/hr is said to use about 150 watts of power. For this hypothetical adult, how much energy is consumed in a 1-hour walk?


 sbk-7-fjfk

   130 Cal Â Â Â Â Â   260 Cal Â Â Â Â Â   1.5 Wh Â Â Â Â Â   15 Wh Â Â Â Â Â    





In the exercise/diet literature itâ€™s said that walking a mile consumes about 100 kcal.

Â Â   sbk-8-ywr

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    


 This is (roughly) consistent with the 150 watts of power claimed when waking at 2.5 mi/hr.





Exercise 2 Â 

The three temperature scalesâ€”C, F, and Kâ€”define zero degrees differently. This make it hard to do the conversion in oneâ€™s head.
The computational chunk that follows provides two functions, FtoC() and FtoK()

FtoC( 72 )
FtoK( 98.6)


What is the change in C when F increases by 10 degrees?


 dfs-1-is4

   0.556 degrees Â Â Â Â Â   5.56 degrees C Â Â Â Â Â   -5.56 degrees C Â Â Â Â Â   5.56 degrees F Â Â Â Â Â    





What is the rate of change of C with respect to F?


 dfs-2-krod


 0.556 degrees C


 1.8 degrees C


 0.556 degrees C / degrees F


 1.8 degrees C / degrees F







What is the dimension of the rate of change of C with respect to F?


 dfs-3-owe


 dimensionless


 ğ›³


 ğ›³-1


 ğ›³-2




















NoteDrill for Chapter 4





Open drill questions in this document
Remember to submit your drill answers through that document. But for the exercises in the present document, use the â€œcollect answersâ€ at the top of this page.









NoteChapter Four






3.4.5.



Exercise 3 Â 

Consider the data on the body mass (kg) and brain mass (gm) for 62 species of mammals shown in FigureÂ 1. (You can hover the cursor over a point to see the species name.)








FigureÂ 1





The lessor short-tailed shrew has both the smallest body mass and brain mass. What is the brain mass of the short-tailed shrew? (Pick the answer thatâ€™s closest.)


 msp-1-4lse

   0.03 gm Â Â Â Â Â   0.14 gm Â Â Â Â Â   0.52 gm Â Â Â Â Â    





The water opposum, arctic fox, nine-banded armadillo, and rock hyrax (in the middle of the cloud of points) all have about the same body mass. What is that body mass? (Pick the answer thatâ€™s closest.)


 msp-2-sddo

   1-2 kg Â Â Â Â Â   3-4 kg Â Â Â Â Â   6-7 kg Â Â Â Â Â   8-9 kg Â Â Â Â Â    





Which of these animals has a body mass closest to 10 kg?


 msp-3-fhsl

   raccoon Â Â Â Â Â   baboon Â Â Â Â Â   roe deer Â Â Â Â Â   vervet Â Â Â Â Â    





Of the mammals in the range of body masses from 10 to 100 kg, which has the smallest brain size?


 msp-4-le4

   water opposum Â Â Â Â Â   giant armadillo Â Â Â Â Â   goat Â Â Â Â Â   kangaroo Â Â Â Â Â    









Exercise 4 Â 

The Engine data frame, which contains measurements of many different internal combustion engines of widely varying sizes. For instance, we can graph engine RPM (revolutions per second) versus engine mass (in pounds), as in FigureÂ 2.








FigureÂ 2: Engine speed (RPM) versus mass for 39 different engines using linear axes. Applications for engines span many magnitudes: compare a small lawn-mower engine to the huge engine in a large ship.





In the FigureÂ 2, most engines have a mass ofâ€¦ zero. At least, that is how it appears. The scale of the horizontal axis is determined only by the two massive 100,000-pound monster engines plotted at the right end of the graph.
Plotting the magnitude of the engine mass spreads things out, as in FigureÂ 3.












(a)











(b)







FigureÂ 3: The engine data plotted with magnitude scales





Which of the plots in FigureÂ 3 uses two magnitude axes?


 zdb-1-8dw

   (a) Â Â Â Â Â   (b) Â Â Â Â Â   both a and b Â Â Â Â Â   neither a nor b Â Â Â Â Â    





In FigureÂ 3, there is an unlabelled vertical grid line half-way between 100 and 10,000 pounds. What is an appropriate label?


 zdb-3-k4s

   500 Â Â Â Â Â   550 Â Â Â Â Â   1000 Â Â Â Â Â   3000 Â Â Â Â Â    









Exercise 5 Food and medicine are measured over a large range. For instance, in the metric system, measurements might be denominated in micrograms, milligrams, grams, kilograms. How many orders of magnitude (that is, factors of 10) are spanned from micrograms to kilograms.

 asm-1-wels

   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â   6 Â Â Â Â Â   8 Â Â Â Â Â   9 Â Â Â Â Â   10 Â Â Â Â Â   12

NoteChapter One






1.2.



Exercise 1 Many people experience the symptoms of a housing shortage: splitting up apartments to accomodate roommate groups; financial stress due (in part) to high rents; deferring life decisions such as having children; living in deteriorating, aging buildings, and so on.
Weâ€™re used to thinking about people in terms of lifespan, but it is also useful to think about buildings that way. City and local governments keep detailed information about the housing stock, largely for tax purposes. Services like <zillow.com> have data readily available to the public.
Question: What about the houses listed on Zillow might presented a view biased to houses in better condition?


A life-cycle assessment of a sample of US houses and apartments by Aktas and Bilic (2012) produced the following graphic about how long houses and apartments remain habitable.






FigureÂ 1: â€œLifetime distribution of residential buildings calculated from multiple American Housing Survey microdata,â€ from Aktas and Bilic 2012.



Question: Is the graph consistent with the claim that 7% of US housing stock was built before 1920?


Question: Speculate on what might account for the rightward shift of the curve over the ten year period considered. Consider these two hypotheses:

house building techniques have been improving. (When would they have had to improve to produce the curve shift?)
the current housing shortage has resulted in buildings being used after the time that they would have been replaced were there no housing shortage?









Exercise 2 Consider this simple, made-up mortality table that might be representative of a bird species, e.g.Â robins.



Age
Mortality
Starting Population




0

1000


1
0.50
500


2
0.50
250


3
1.00
125


4

0



Calculate the life expectancy for these birds. Give a number, but also explain you reasoning in words. (Hint: Itâ€™s not a long calculation.)
















NoteDrill for chapter two





Open drill questions in this document
Remember to submit your drill answers through that document. But for the exercises in the present document, use the â€œcollect answersâ€ at the top of this page.









NoteChapter Two






4.5.



Exercise 3 Name five units for energy. Remember that â€œpowerâ€ has a different dimension than energy.







Exercise 4 Light bulbs generally have a quantity printed on them: the wattage. Similarly, light-bulb sockets often have a â€œmax wattsâ€ label advising the user of the largest wattage bulb that can work safely in the socket.

Part a

What is the dimension of a watt?



 bulb-wattage

   Energy Â Â Â Â Â   Power Â Â Â Â Â   Electrical voltage Â Â Â Â Â   Electrical current Â Â Â Â Â    











TipAnswer





Since people donâ€™t directly perceive electrical current or voltage, it is hard to form an intuition about them. Instead, training is required to interpret properly the meanings of electrical dimensions.
An exact mathematical analogy to electrical dimensions can be made to water and flow. You turn on the shower and step in for four minutes. As you shower, at each instant you can feel the â€œintensityâ€ (flow) of the spray from the shower-head. You even have a faucet to set the flow. This flow is analogous to the power used by a light bulb.
Over the full course of your 4-minute shower, six gallons of water goes down the train. Gallons, of course, have the dimension of volume. You used those six gallons over four minutes. Consequently, the flow of water is \(\frac{6\, \text{gallons}}{4\, \text{minutes}} = 1.5\, \text{gallons per minute}\). The volume of water used in your shower session is analogous to the energy used by a light bulb: it is power multiplied by duration. ..id..





Part b

The brightness of the light emitted by a light bulb is proportional to power. Suppose you turn on a 20-watt light when you walk into a room. This consumes energy. The energy used by the bulb is the power multiplied by the duration that the light was on.



If you stay in the room for 1 hour, turning off the light when you leave, how much energy has the light consumed?


 light-bulb-b1

   20 watts Â Â Â Â Â   20 watt-hours Â Â Â Â Â   Not enough information is given Â Â Â Â Â   1 hour Â Â Â Â Â    





In terms of the fundamental dimensionsâ€”L, M, Tâ€”energy has dimension L2 M T-2. What is the dimension of power?


 light-bulb-b2

   L2 M T-1 Â Â Â Â Â   L2 M T-2 Â Â Â Â Â   L2 M T-3 Â Â Â Â Â    





You might reasonably ask, â€œWhat does mass have to do with energy?â€ Perhaps you remember Einsteinâ€™s famous equation for energy: \[E = m\, c^2\] where \(m\) is mass and \(c\) is the speed of light. What is the dimension of \(c^2\)?


 light-bulb-b3

   L T Â Â Â Â Â   L Â Â Â Â Â   L T-1 Â Â Â Â Â   L T-2 Â Â Â Â Â   L2 T-2 Â Â Â Â Â    




Consequently, \(m\, c^2\) has the dimension of energy.

Part c

Consider this statement:



Power consumption is a property of the light bulb, but energy consumption involves both the light bulb itself and the pattern of usage.

Â Â   light-bulb-c1

   True Â Â Â  or Â Â Â Â Â   False Â Â Â Â Â    




Part d

A typical household uses about 10 kilowatt-hours of energy per day. â€œ10 kilowatt-hoursâ€ is an amount of energy, but â€œenergy per dayâ€ is a flow of energy, that is, a power.



Translate â€œ10 kilowatt-hours of energy per dayâ€ into the equivalent watts. For simplicity in the calculation, assume that the energy is used evenly over the 24-hour day.


 light-bulb-d1

   417 watts Â Â Â Â Â   10,000 watts Â Â Â Â Â   240,000 watts Â Â Â Â Â   Not enough information Â Â Â Â Â    





Look up the power consumption of a hand-held blow-dryer. When the blow-dryer is in use, energy consumption of the household increases. Which of these is a plausible fraction of average household power consumed by the hair-dryer?


 light-bulb-d2

   10% of average power Â Â Â Â Â   50% of average power Â Â Â Â Â   100% of average power Â Â Â Â Â   200% of average power
